awd_titl_txt: Identifying a new circuit that controls feeding behavior: leptin and serotonin interactions.
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Abstract

Feeding is an essential activity for the maintenance of life, and its regulation is associated with multiple brain mechanisms that work together to ensure that animals eat appropriately. The complexity of these interactions has presented challenges to our efforts to fully appreciate the neural basis of food intake. However, before we can understand that complexity we must first identify the individual brain circuits that regulate food intake. The main goal of this project is therefore to use advanced genetic and anatomical approaches to identify a novel circuit that contributes to the control of feeding behavior. Identifying this circuit will ultimately allow us to determine how it works together with other feeding circuits that we already know more about to regulate a complex behavior critical for animal survival. In achieving that goal the work will not only increase our understanding of fundamental principles associated with how the brain regulates behavior, but may also lead to unexpected insights into feeding disorders and the chronic medical conditions associated with them that create considerable economic and social burdens, nationally and globally. In addition, this project includes a Summer Internship Program that will provide an integrated research experience for undergraduate students, particularly students who will be recruited from populations that are under-represented in science and medicine. These research experiences will provide such students with experiential learning opportunities that will create a foundation for future success in biomedical or basic research science.

Technical Abstract

Many studies agree that leptin controls food intake through activation of hypothalamic leptin receptors (LepRs). In addition, recent reports have examined the participation of extra-hypothalamic LepRs. In this regard, we have identified neurons in the rat raphe nuclei that are activated by leptin. Intra raphe administration of leptin increases pSTAT3 expression in discrete serotonergic neurons and suppresses food intake. Using optogenetic approaches, we were able to inhibit feeding behavior when the raphe neurons responsive to leptin were photo-stimulated, and we showed that intra-raphe leptin increases hypothalamic 5-HT levels.zpur overarching hypothesis is therefore that, in addition to direct hypothalamic actions, leptin powerfully regulates food intake by activating LepRs located in the raphe nuclei, thus stimulating 5-HT release in the hypothalamic nuclei where 5-HT exerts anorectic effect. The current project will test this hypothesis by studying the functional anatomical serotonergic connections between the raphe and the hypothalamic nuclei, measuring in vivo 5-HT release in the hypothalamic nuclei that receive serotonergic terminals following optogenetic stimulation of leptin responsive neurons of the raphe nuclei; and identifying the phenotype of the hypothalamic neurons that are activated by leptin-stimulated serotonin release. The idea that leptin is acting at multiple target sites including serotonergic neurons in the raphe will advance our understanding of the regulation of feeding behavior. This research will also be used to provide in-depth research opportunities for students from a nearby liberal arts college, particularly students from under-represented populations.

Intellectual Merit:

 

Feeding is an essential behavior for the maintenance of life; therefore, the feeding behavior requires an extremely precise control that includes the interaction of different mechanisms to function adequately. There is a myriad of body signals that exert a fine modulation of this vital behavior. Some of these signals come from the periphery and others from the brain. In the central nervous system, several neurotransmitters/neuromodulators and neurocircuits orchestrate their activities to regulate food intake. My research project focused on the identification of a novel circuit that involves two brain areas: 1) the dorsal raphe nuclei and 2) the hypothalamic nuclei. The participation of the raphe nuclei in the regulation of food intake through the action of peripheral hormones opens new roads of investigations about feeding behavior. Our research has a clear impact in the eating behavior field; however, this impact is not confined to the regulation of food intake, it goes beyond that since eating disorders are associated to a great variety of pathologies such as obesity, diabetes, malnutrition, cancer, and neuropsychiatric disorders such as anorexia nervosa and depression. Understanding the physiology of this novel circuit could be an instrumental first step to know how to restore the normal physiology when the circuit is disrupted and leads to abnormal eating behavior.

We were able to demonstrate that the raphe nuclei participate in the regulation of feeding behavior. This subject was very controversial in the field of ingestive behavior; and now using different approaches we demonstrated that a hormone released by the adipose tissue, named leptin, can work directly on the raphe nuclei inhibiting food intake in rats. The raphe nuclei are the main source of serotonin in the brain, and this neurotransmitter has an anorectic effect per se. This project allowed us to better understand the interactions between leptin and serotonin to decrease feeding behavior. In addition to the eating behavior, we were able to describe the neuroanatomical connections between the raphe neurons that send projections to the arcuate nucleus of the hypothalamus, and how the activation of the raphe neurons sensitive to leptin increases the serotonin efflux in the arcuate nucleus of the hypothalamus.

Since the topic is very controversial in the field of feeding behavior, using state-of-the-art techniques strengthened our studies and allowed us to deeply characterize this novel circuit that starts in the raphe neurons and projects to hypothalamus.

Moreover, we are convinced that this new role of the raphe on eating behavior is not limited to the interaction between serotonin and leptin, and we are very enthusiastic on going beyond and investigate how other neurotransmitters affect this brain area and regulate the feeding behavior.

 

Broader Impacts

 

This project allowed me to train eight undergraduate students from the College of Charleston. These students were working full-time during the summer, and they were trained in a variety of neuroscience techniques, and participated in weekly lab meetings, seminars, and a workshop series to prepare them for graduate school. These undergraduate students presented their research in local meetings at the University of South Carolina and College of Charleston, and also at the Society for Neuroscience (SFN) Meetings in Chicago, IL, San Diego, CA, and Washington, DC. After their participation in the NSF funded internship, these students continued their studies in the field of the sciences. Six out of these eight undergraduate students belong to underrepresented groups in science. For most of them this NSF-funded hands-on experience was their first approach to research. For many of them this was a transformative experience, which helped them decide their career goals, having a positive impact on their professional lives.

This NSF award greatly contributed to the academic success of all the students that participated in the summer internship. All of them continue in the science field, and gratefully recognize that their NSF research experience was fundamental for the future of their careers. All these students are committed to giving back to society as mentors or advisors for new generations of scientists, strengthening the importance of focusing the efforts on underserved communities.
